attributes.action: everyone should stay in paediatrics till 18
attributes.background: children stay under paediatric services at hospitals until the age of 16 However for teens age 16-18 there is a gap because you are to old for paediatrics services yet you are to young for adult and this leads to an impact on treatment for no team will be able to take your case or provide treatment.

attributes.action: To implement a Child Domestic Abuse Law.
attributes.background:
It's positive that children are recognised as victims in their own right. 
We however observe that there is no particular guidance on how this application, should impact decision making for social services, CAFCASS or indeed the Courts. We are asking for this to change.
attributes.additional_details:
The current law gives children no rights. Protective legislation will uphold their voices on matters that affect them.
We want paramount consideration that even if the perpetrator has not been directly abusive to the child. Growing up in an environment of hostility and abuse, whether it physical, psychological, emotional or sexual, will mean the child is a victim not just from being present in the home but from seeing the parent who is a victim suffer whether that be physically or emotionally.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

There is already legislation relating to the domestic abuse of children, and we're not sure exactly what changes you'd like the Government or Parliament to make to the law.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Change our time to permanent British summertime
attributes.background: Around 1 in 3 people suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder in the UK; moving permanently to British summertime could greatly combat this. Rather than wasting the hour of light in the morning, on a commute or in an office, we could utilise it after work, for socialising and outdoor activities.
attributes.additional_details:
The key benefits:

Health: People could use the longer evenings to socialise and engage in leisure activities such as sport.

Safety: It could prevent 80 deaths and more than 200 serious injuries on UK roads every year.

Environment: CO2 pollution could be reduced by at least 447,000 tonnes each year, due to a lower electricity demand for artificial light in the evenings.

Tourism: UK tourism industry could be boosted by £1bn every year due to longer and lighter days.

attributes.action: Change the speed limit back to 30mph from 20mph in London between 10pm and 6am.
attributes.background: Change the speed limit from 20mph to 30mph in London after 10pm at night until 6am in the morning as the current limits of 20mph at these times do not create a safer environment but can cause conflict between road users and seem to serve no purpose other than as a means of collecting revenue.
attributes.additional_details: For example at 2am in the morning a 20mph speed limit is ridiculous on most London roads. Everyone I have spoken to agrees with this common sense approach. 20mph on Millbank at 3 in the morning is painfully slow.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about local speed limits are a matter for local traffic authorities, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here:
https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Devolve powers to councils to set their own housing targets
attributes.background:
Councils are too often faced with housing targets that can only be achieved by concreting over significant amounts of green space, with massive damage to the environment and quality of life.

Central government calculations play too large a role in determining local housing needs and numbers.
attributes.additional_details:
We call for: 

- Greater powers for councils to determine their own housing needs and numbers, free from the influence of centralised calculations

- New policies to provide stronger protection for greenfield sites and prioritisation of brownfield development

- Support for those seeking to deliver truly affordable housing, such as community land trusts

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.  We're not sure whether you want Government targets for local housebuilding to be scrapped or something else. We're also not sure what 'new policies' and 'support' you'd like to see. 

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Change GCSE exam conditions.
attributes.background: I want Parliament to change the way GCSE exams are held & to make it a more relaxed environment. Reducing stress & pressure the current GCSE curriculum & exam program has on students.
attributes.additional_details: As a person with autism I have struggled with mock exams when they have been under standard GCSE conditions. From experience the high levels of pressure that come from being under exam conditions has caused me to not do as well as I know I can in my exams. If the exam conditions were to be more relaxed and de-pressurised I believe I would perform so much better in my exams & I am certain that students all across the nation fell the same way.

attributes.action: Children 0 - 6 years should not have to disclose sexual abuse to police directly
attributes.background: Change policy surrounding the way evidence is used when prosecuting the perpetrators of sexual abuse. When young children disclose abuse to people they know and trust (eg, family members and nursery workers) the CPS should take their witness statements as evidence to prosecute abusers.
attributes.additional_details: Even when several witness statements are provided and there is some form of medical physical evidence of sexual abuse young children are encouraged to disclose abuse to the police. What the child says in the police interview influences the final decision whether to prosecute abusers. Despite, other evidence. It is unfair to pressure young children to speak to strangers (police) in an unfamiliar environment. Carer's are not allowed in the interview room too but the abuser is allowed a solicitor!

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about when, and on what evidence, to prosecute someone for child sexual offences are a matter for the Crown Prosecution Service, not the Government or Parliament.

Children, or their parents, can already decline to speak directly to the police about allegations of child sexual offences.

You can find out how to report child abuse, and get support here: https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse

attributes.action: All children to litter pick in the community as part of their school education.
attributes.background:
Create a compulsory citizenship award for all school children which schools would deliver as part of their primary and secondary education.
This would include a focus on their responsibility to and impact on the environment, with all school children doing termly litter picks in the community.
attributes.additional_details: I am part of a local litter picking group (www.macclitter.org) and it is clear that the problem of litter is growing and that the education of children it vital to make on impact on this issue. We have tried, with limited success to far, to engage local schools. This issue needs central direction and to be integrated into the core education syllabus at both primary and secondary level. If all children got actively involved in this important issue, then it would make a big long term difference.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

The Government sets the national curriculum, which sets the programmes of study schools in England are required to teach, but what arranging for children to take part in activities such as litter picking would be a matter for individual schools, not the Government or Parliament.

As a result it is not possible for the Government or Parliament to take the action you have requested.

attributes.action: Ban use of treatment for companion animals that contain Fipronil & Imidacloprid

attributes.additional_details: If we do not ban these chemicals, it will continue to have a significant impact on our aquatic life and birds. Much more stringent tests must be put in place, to ensure over the counter and prescription treatments will not end up in the wider environment causing death and pollution.

attributes.action: Make it policy to label supermarket food products with their carbon impact
attributes.background: Introduce a mandatory requirement to label supermarket food products with information about their impact on the environment. In order to reduce our food-related impact as consumers, we need clear, accessible information about the carbon footprint associated with the production of food products.

attributes.additional_details: At the moment, if you are caught littering the penalty amount is currently £150 which has to be paid within 14 days from the issue date. rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for. Decisions about management of littering in particular areas are a matter for individual local authorities, not the Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

You could raise this issue with a local councillor, who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

We could accept a petition calling for wider changes to penalties for littering, but it would need to be clear in the title of your petition that this is what you want to happen.

We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Increase fixed penalty fines for littering: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/581996

attributes.action: Vigorously enforce speed limits to reduce carbon emissions.
attributes.background: At a time when many of us are working hard to reduce our carbon footprints there appears to be a sizeable minority of drivers who think it is acceptable to drive well above the 70mph limit, thereby dramatically increasing the CO2 emissions of their vehicle per mile travelled.
attributes.additional_details:
There are a number of ways this could be achieved, including speed limiters, tracking devices, more speed cameras, reducing the amount of leeway given by existing cameras, more traffic police and educating the public about the relationship of increasing speed to increasing emissions. 
Changing the culture so that we view excessive speed as more likely to result in a fine, antisocial, dangerous and damaging to the environment could result in a significant reduction in CO2 emissions very quickly.

rejection.details:
Petitions must call for a specific action that the UK Government or House of Commons is responsible for.

Decisions about enforcing speed limits are a matter for the police and local traffic authorities, not the Government or House of Commons. As a result it is not possible for the Government or House of Commons to take the action you have requested.

We could accept a petition calling on the Government to provide additional funding for traffic enforcement, or a public awareness campaign about the environmental impact of speeding, if either of those are things you'd like to happen.
